title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under which the Secretary of Transportation will make grants to state and local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects such as highway and bridge improvements. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects including road improvements, public transportation, rail projects, port infrastructure, aviation projects, and water infrastructure. Coordination is required for these projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects including road improvements, public transportation, rail projects, port infrastructure, aviation projects, and water infrastructure. Coordination is required for these projects, with specific requirements for water infrastructure projects. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Secretary, and criteria for grant awards will be specified by the Secretary within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will issue regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment for grant criteria, including financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100%, and grants should be distributed equitably and address urban and rural needs. In making grants under subsection (b), the Secretary ensures equitable distribution geographically, addresses urban and rural needs, promotes veteran training and employment, and requires a percentage of grant amounts to be spent through small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Projects funded by these grants must comply with Title 40 requirements and adhere to Buy America provisions. The Buy America provision in the project funding under Title 40 requires all iron, steel, and manufactured goods to be produced in the United States, with exceptions allowed if it's not in the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities, or increases project costs by more than 25 percent. The Buy America provision mandates that goods for projects funded under Title 40 must be produced in the United States, with exceptions for cases where it's not in the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities, or increases project costs by over 25 percent. The Secretary must provide detailed justification for any waivers granted, and the provision must align with U.S. international agreements. Additionally, transparency and accountability measures are required for grant utilization, public information availability, and congressional reporting. The Department of Transportation must provide information on grants made under subsection (b) to Congress annually. The Secretary must coordinate with other federal departments to streamline environmental reviews for projects funded by grants. $985 billion is authorized for grants under the program from 2016 to 2020, with 85% of the funds allocated for eligible projects. The Secretary will use allocated funds for grants for various project types from fiscal years 2016 to 2020, with specific percentages designated for each project category. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specified characteristics. Proceeds from the bonds will be used by the Secretary of Transportation for the program outlined in the Act. Additionally, a report is required. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
